messageBody:
Ron Jeffries wrote:
> On Sunday, May 2, 2004, at 9:15:01 AM, Thomas L Roche <tlroche@...>
> wrote:
>
> > ) it was at one time legitimate to say "I can't xUnit my UI, so I will
> > try to do the best I can," i.e. create a thin UI well-separated from
> > its model and control. But it was *never* legitimate to make a virtue
> > of necessity, to say (as you do) that "separation is the solution."
> > Now that you *can* drive your UIs from JUnit, and therefore you can
> > *fully* test your UIs, your claim is illegitimate, and moreover
> > encourages the "anti-test-infection."
>
> I resemble this remark, and it's hard to refute.
>
> I still don't have the necessary skill to do very well what Thomas rightly
> recommends, but I believe that he's right.

Separation is, however, a majority of the solution. It is easily 80% of
the solution, if not more. I hope that readers do not interpret your
remark to mean that separation is ineffective.

I used not to know how to write object tests for dynamic web page
templates, and after a few projects spent making those templates too
simple to break, I felt confident enough to try testing them. That's how
it went for me: when I tried testing them, the cost of failure was low,
because so much of the logic involved with the user interface was
already tested elsewhere. That gave me the confidence not to worry about
whether my UI testing was adequate--if it wasn't, then that wasn't the
end of the world.

It turns out that writing object tests for web page templates isn't that
difficult. It turns out that writing object tests for Swing UIs isn't
that difficult, either (thanks to Dave Astels). That's not to say,
though, that the journey through "I can't do it, so I'll make my UI too
simple to break" wasn't well worth it.
